Award.AwardTitle: Dispersion, Chemical Functionalization and Dynamics of Boron-Nitride Nanotubides
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Angel A. Mart√≠ and Professor Matteo Pasquali of Rice University to study the properties of tubular nanostructures made of boron and nitrogen known as boron-nitride nanotubes (BNNTs). The goals of this research are to develop methods to chemically modify the surface of BNNTs and to study their solution behavior. Controlling the surface chemistry and organization of BNNT in solution will allow their utilization as building blocks for a variety of applications including high strength materials, water purification membranes, heat dissipation materials, and antifouling agents. While exploring the chemistry of BNNTs, the PIs pursue broader impact activities to broaden the participation of underrepresented minorities in science and engineering careers and to disseminate chemistry, engineering, and nanoscience concepts to the larger community.

BNNTs are the ultimate building blocks for the manufacture of nanoarchitectures and novel macroscopic assemblies. However their chemical functionalization, dispersion, and phase behavior in liquids, and thus their self-assembly into supramolecular ordered structures, are still challenges in this field of research. In order to address these challenges, the proposed research involves synthesizing negatively charged BNNTs, or boron nitrides nanotubides (BNNTDs). The BNNTD properties provide control over the dispensability, chemical properties, and solution dynamics of BNNTs. This project involves studying how to prepare BNNTDs by chemical reduction and the functionalization of the BNNT surface by reaction of BNNTDs with alkyl and aryl halides. The solution dynamics of BNNTs are studied using microscopy techniques. The results of this research will accelerate the maturation of BNNT science and technology, which is expected to provide new supramolecular structures with unusual combinations of properties (e.g., strong, flexible, electrically insulating, thermally conductive fibers). The research not only advances the state-of-knowledge in nanoscience, but also promotes the discovery and understanding of advanced nanotechnology concepts by graduate and undergraduate students. The educational plan includes offering talks to underrepresented minority students from K-12 to graduate school about different topics such as nanotechnology research, careers in science and engineering, and graduate school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoscience has advanced our understanding of how to manipulate structures that are at least 10 million times smaller than a meter (< 100 nm).  The study of nanostructures has come to revolutionize our understanding of science, with novel ways to dictate shape, structure, and function. This field had its beginnings with the discovery of a molecular cluster of 60 carbon atoms, by Smalley, Curl, and Kroto, that formed an icosahedron similar to a soccer ball. This nanoscale soccer ball was called buckministerfullerene and is an example of a zero dimensional nanostructure. One dimensional nanostructures have the shape of cylinders, with diameters in the nanoscale and lengths of hundreds of nanometers. The most famous one dimensional structure is the carbon nanotube. Carbon nanotubes are completely made from carbon atoms and can be visualized as a single graphite layer (graphene) rolled to form a cylinder. Carbon nanotubes have many outstanding properties, such as their light weight (lighter than aluminum), high strength (higher than steel), and heat conduction (better than pure diamond). In addition, depending on how the graphene sheet is rolled to form the carbon nanotube, they can have electrical properties that range from semiconducting to conducting. These properties make carbon nanotubes the ideal candidates for the new generation of electronic circuits and sensors, with the caveat that carbon nanotubes lack an electrically insulating type. Fortunately, a novel kind of nanostructure has emerged that has the structure of carbon nanotubes, but is formed, instead, from alternating boron and nitrogen atoms. These boron-nitride nanotubes have properties similar to carbon nanotubes, such as their light weight, high strength and high heat conduction, but are electrically insulating. Therefore, boron-nitride nanotubes bridge the gap of properties necessary for novel advanced electronics.

We have been doing research on carbon nanotubes for years; reporting on their self-assembly to form liquid crystals, continuous fibers (or wires) of macroscopic size, and hybrid materials with graphene. During this research, we also became interested in how to control the properties of boron-nitride nanotubes. We studied the chemical grafting of boron nitride nanotubes with different chemical groups. For example, plastics (polymers) with different chemical groups have been used for different applications, where the properties of the materials can be tuned depending on the groups grafted to their surfaces. Following that same principle, we attached carbon chains (greasy molecules) to the surface of boron-nitride nanotubes, and studied how the nanotubes? properties were modified. In addition to being able to create hybrid materials, we need to understand how to disaggregate these useful building blocks. We discovered that molecules called surfactants (a kind of detergent) can do this job. Surfactants have a part that attach to the nanotubes and a part that is soluble in water. This allows the nanotubes, which are usually repelled by water, to become more compatible with water and to be dispersed. Additionally, in order to track the movement of nanotubes in solution, we developed a new kind of surfactant that is fluorescent (a fluorescent detergent). This surfactant wraps around nanotubes and enables their monitoring using fluorescence microscopy. Now, using this technique, we are studying the diffusion and rotation of nanotubes in solution.

This work has advanced our knowledge of boron nitride nanotubes, allowing their functionalization, dispersion, and visualization. These advances have paved the way for the use of these structures for advanced electronics and sensing. The ability to modify the surface of nanotubes with a variety of groups will allow for better compatibility for the fabrication of novel hybrid materials and devices, which will be used in the construction of the next generation of planes, cars, buildings, and space ships.

Two professors (principal investigators), three graduate students, and several undergraduate students worked throughout the two years of this project, generating the data that has been shared with the scientific community through peer-reviewed publications and with the public through press releases. The graduate and undergraduate students have been trained in advanced research techniques, state-of-the-art analytical instrumentation and microscopy, and presentation skills. Other activities have included presentations to underrepresented minority students at different institutions and summer research opportunities for high school students.
